review.title: Zonotope Hit-and-run for Efficient Sampling from Projection DPPs
review.abstract: Determinantal point processes (DPPs) are distributions over sets of items that model diversity using kernels. Their applications in machine learning include summary extraction and recommendation systems. Yet, the cost of sampling from a DPP is prohibitive in large-scale applications, which has triggered an effort towards efficient approximate samplers. We build a novel MCMC sampler that combines ideas from combinatorial geometry, linear programming, and Monte Carlo methods to sample from DPPs with a fixed sample cardinality, also called projection DPPs. Our sampler leverages the ability of the hit-and-run MCMC kernel to efficiently move across convex bodies. Previous theoretical results yield a fast mixing time of our chain when targeting a distribution that is close to a projection DPP, but not a DPP in general. Our empirical results demonstrate that this extends to sampling projection DPPs, i.e., our sampler is more sample-efficient than previous approaches.
histories: 12 pages, 12 figures, 2 columns, accepted to ICML 2017

metadata.title: Zonotope Hit-and-run for Efficient Sampling from Projection DPPs

sections.heading: 4.2. Text Summarization
sections.text: To illustrate this, we adapt an experiment by Kulesza & Taskar (2012, Section 4.2.1) on minimal Bayes risks to summary extraction, the idea being to find a sentence Y of sentences in a text that maximizes: 1R ∑ r = 1 ROUGE-1F (Y, Yr), (12) where (Yr) r are decoded from a projection of DPP. ROUGE1F is a measure of the similarity of two sentences in a text that maximizes: The summary of this 64-sentence article as a subset of 11 sentences. In this setting, the evaluation of one ROUGE-1F in sum (12) is a measure of the similarity of two sentences of sentences.

sections.heading: 5. Discussion
sections.text: This MCMC kernel uses optimization algorithms to perform global movements on a convex body representing the DPP. We provided empirical results that support its rapid mixing compared to the state-of-the-art base exchange chain by Anari et al. (2016); Li et al. (2016b). Future work will focus on implementation: While our MCMC chain mixes faster, our algorithm suffers from having to solve linear programs at every iteration compared to the CPU time. We note that even answering the question of whether a particular point belongs to a zonotope involves linear programming, so that chord finding methods used in the sample (Neal, 2003, Sections 4 and 5) would not offer significant computational savings. We also plan to examine theoretical limits on the mixing time of our algorithm.

sections.heading: A. Landmarks on MNIST
sections.text: To illustrate our algorithm 5 using a non-synthetic dataset, we take a thousand images of handwritten 1s from the MNIST. We consider the problem of finding landmarks among these 1s, see, for example, Liang & Paisley (2015). To obtain a set of r = 10 landmarks from a DPP projection, we design r-dimensional feature vectors of our images, whose inner products indicate similarity. Specifically, we take A as the coordinates of the projections of our dataset on the first r main directions given by a standard PCA, so that A ranks r if all the variance is not explained by these first r eigenvalues. Note that our choice of the standard PCA is arbitrary: For multiple landmarks, we could show the coordinate output through a diverse learning algorithm such as ISOMAP.Running our algorithm 5 for 10,000 time steps.

metadata.abstractText: Determinantal point processes (DPPs) are distributions over sets of items that model diversity using kernels. Their applications in machine learning include summary extraction and recommendation systems. Yet, the cost of sampling from a DPP is prohibitive in large-scale applications, which has triggered an effort towards efficient approximate samplers. We build a novel MCMC sampler that combines ideas from combinatorial geometry, linear programming, and Monte Carlo methods to sample from DPPs with a fixed sample cardinality, also called projection DPPs. Our sampler leverages the ability of the hit-and-run MCMC kernel to efficiently move across convex bodies. Previous theoretical results yield a fast mixing time of our chain when targeting a distribution that is close to a projection DPP, but not a DPP in general. Our empirical results demonstrate that this extends to sampling projection DPPs, i.e., our sampler is more sample-efficient than previous approaches which in turn translates to faster convergence when dealing with costlyto-evaluate functions, such as summary extraction in our experiments.
